Introduction

Oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) is characterized by a pervasive pattern of argumentative and defiant behavior toward authority figures.  Some children with ODD may also experience chronic anger/irritability and vindictiveness.  The behaviors often manifest at home with family members but can also extend to interactions with other individuals (eg, teachers, peers).  Initial symptoms typically start around age 4-5 and must be excessive in frequency and duration when compared to normative, age-appropriate behaviors.

Epidemiology and risk factors



ODD is estimated to have a prevalence rate from 1%-10% and is more common in boys than in girls prior to adolescence.



The etiology of ODD is multifactorial and can include a combination environmental (eg, child abuse, harsh discipline styles) and genetic (eg, family history of conduct disorder, bipolar disorder, or substance use disorder).  In addition, patients may have abnormalities of the prefrontal cortex and amygdala, which may contribute to emotional dysregulation as well as impaired impulse control and judgment.

Diagnosis



For a diagnosis of ODD, patients must exhibit a minimum of 4 symptoms from any of the following categories for â‰¥6 months:



  • Angry/irritable mood (eg, loses temper easily)
  • Argumentative/defiant behavior (eg, refuses to comply with rules/requests, blames others for misbehavior)
  • Vindictiveness (eg, seeks revenge, makes hateful insults when angry)


The symptoms must be considered excessive in frequency and severity when compared to normative, age-appropriate behaviors.  Behaviors can be limited to a single setting (most commonly at home) but must occur with at least 1 individual who is not a sibling (eg, parents, teachers, peers).  Initial symptoms typically start around age 4-5, but ODD can be diagnosed at any age.

Differential diagnosis



Disruptive behaviors can occur in normal development and other disorders, but the level of severity and frequency of behaviors distinguish ODD from other conditions:



  • Developmentally appropriate behavior: can consist of temper outbursts in children and challenging rules and authority figures in adolescents.  However, these behaviors are more severe and frequent in ODD, causing significant social and academic dysfunction (eg, lack of meaningful relationships, suspension from school).


  • Conduct disorder: is characterized by severe and aggressive behaviors (eg, cruelty toward people or animals, destruction of property, stealing), but it is not associated with significant mood (eg, irritability, anger) symptoms.
  • Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD): DMDD and ODD symptoms are characterized by chronic irritability and temper outbursts.  However, outbursts in DMDD are more frequent and severe (eg, causing physical aggression/property destruction).
  • Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD): is a common comorbidity in children with ODD.  It may be distinguished from ODD if oppositional behaviors and irritability/anger occur only in situations that require focus/sustained attention.


Accurate diagnosis of disruptive behaviors allows for appropriate treatment and interventions (eg, stimulants for ADHD, assessing and addressing safety concerns for conduct disorder).

Management



Treatment of ODD consists of psychosocial interventions, including:



  • Behavioral parent management training teaches parents how to use positive reinforcement, reward systems, and praise to promote more adaptive behaviors and strengthen the parent-child relationship.
  • For older children, cognitive-behavioral therapy helps teach coping and social skills to reduce angry outbursts and improve emotional regulation.
  • School-based interventions such as developing routines, acknowledging positive behaviors, and addressing problem behaviors in private may reduce disruptions in the classroom.


Pharmacotherapy is reserved for cases of severe agitation/aggression that are unresponsive to psychosocial interventions.  In these cases, treatment with a second-generation antipsychotic can be considered.  Treatment of comorbid conditions (eg, ADHD, trauma-related disorders, mood disorders) should occur in conjunction with behavioral treatments.

Prognosis



ODD can vary in severity, and for many cases of mild to moderate ODD, symptoms tend to improve with age.  However, severe cases can have long-term implications, including the development of conduct disorder and significant social and occupational impairment, resulting in various functional consequences:



  • Strained family relationships
  • Social withdrawal, difficulty establishing and maintaining relationships with peers
  • Poor academic performance
  • Comorbidities (eg, ADHD, major depressive disorder, substance use disorders)


Early diagnosis and intervention, parental involvement, and treatment of comorbidities are associated with improved outcomes.
